phrases.how_to_use: "Sorry" is a general short apology. We use this when we bump into people on the street. At other times, it sounds too weak.
We use 'so', 'very' and 'terribly' to make the meaning stronger. 'Terribly' is the strongest. If we use one of the words in brackets, it is stressed.
We use 'so', 'very' and 'terribly' to make the meaning stronger. 'Terribly' is the strongest. If we use one of the words in brackets, it is stressed.
We use 'so', 'very' and 'terribly' to make the meaning stronger. 'Terribly' is the strongest. If we use one of the words in brackets, it is stressed.
It's quite formal but it's a stronger apology than just 'sorry'.
We use this phrase to criticise ourselves and the mistake that we have just made.

phrases.expression: Please don't be mad at me.
phrases.how_to_use: It's asking the other person not to get angry. The tone is quite informal.
This phrase is the best known phrase but English people don't use it every time.
It's a general inquiry about the other person's health and life. Your answer could be about your health, your work or your personal life.
It's a general inquiry about the other person's health and life but the 'incorrect' grammar makes it much more informal.
It's asking about the other person's life (work or personal life).
It's asking about the other person's life (work or personal life).
It's followed by indirect questions. So 'What's the time?' becomes 'Can you tell me what the time is?'.
It's followed by indirect questions. So 'What's the time?' becomes 'Could you tell me what the time is?'.
It's good to use if you are asking a stranger or you are asking at a public information desk.
This phrase is more informal.

phrases.expression: I wonder if someone could tell me...?
phrases.how_to_use: It's very formal and in an informal situation some people may react strangely if they think that you are being sarcastic.

It's used to say we will phone someone at some time in the future. We can also say 'I'll get back to you' if someone has asked us for specific 
information that we don't have now.
You hear it on an answerphone, asking people to say why they were calling.
You use this phrase to say who you are at the beginning of a call.
We use this phrase to check someone knows that we called and left a message before.

phrases.expression: Can I speak to Rob, please?
phrases.how_to_use: It's a common question if the person you want to talk to is not the person who answers the phone.
It's the most common phrase that people say.
It's a little more formal way to say goodbye.
It's a quite informal and friendly way to say goodbye.
It's a quite informal and friendly way to say goodbye.
It's a quite informal and friendly way to say goodbye.
It's a quite informal and friendly way to say goodbye.

colors.name: purple

colors.name: yellow

colors.name: pink
